Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2012 09:20PM - edited Apr 28, 2012 09:37PM by Jejik I am a lawyer too and while I wouldn't give legal advice here,not that brave lol, i will say that I know more than a few people who work part time and still receive disability, you just need to make under so much a month. And you can't start working part time until once you are already recieving disability. Being able to work ten or so hours a week is very different from being able to work full time and support yourself. Best of luck in making your decision!!
Posts.Title: Working for a living....taking what they're giving... CoolBreeze Linda1966

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2012 07:05PM Jejik wrote: Thank you all so much. I will definitely try contacting katie31. Jamieh, if you do find that blog please let me know, that would be super helpful. My oncologist told me that I should look at this like a gift from God, and I do. But knowing that the Lord givers and the Lord taketh away gets me super anxious sometimes. But I have never wanted anything more in my life for this baby to be born healthy and for me to be able to watch it grow. Cool breeze, I don't think that sounds terrible, especially coming from a mother who worries about hanging on for her son's sake. I didn't mention it, but I am married to a wonderful guy who is already an awesome father to two girls. This baby will have him and two half sisters and lots of extended family that loves it besides me. Maybe it is selfish of me but I cannot imagine giving the baby up for adoption. Just as no matter what doctors said it never crossed my mind to terminate.I already love it do much, and want to be a part of its life for as long as possible. I am doing the journal thing so that if the worst does happen the baby can at least know how much I loved it and what I am like and my thoughts on things. I am just wondering how to cover it all!! I hope to get to know y'all better as I navigate the site more. Thanks again.
Posts.Title: Pregnancy after Stage IV diagnosis Jejik CAROLINE77

Posts.Content: Jejik wrote: I was just wondering if there is anyone out there who has gotten pregnant after a stage four diagnosis. I have been in remission just under a year, and found out a couple of months ago that I am pregnant. I am 33 yeas old, and always wanted children, but after my diagnosis of metastatic disease last year, I gave up on the idea of ever having a child. But here I am. I have decided to have the child, and an ultrasound at twelve weeks shows the baby doing good. I, on the other hand, am a wreck and would give anything to have someone to talk to who has been where I am at. I have to decide what to do about my treatments (have stopped for now), feelings of helplessness over my future, feelings of guilt over the fact that there is a good chance my child will grow up without a mom, the list how's on and on. Even if you have not been through it, if you have any inspirational stories, words of wisdom or hope,,,I would appreciate it so very much. I am a breast cancer fighter, not a survivor. Dx 9/21/2010, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 1/10 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Surgery Lumpectomy: Left; Lymph node removal: Left, Underarm/Axillary Radiation Therapy Targeted Therapy Herceptin (trastuzumab) Chemotherapy Carboplatin (Paraplatin), Taxotere (docetaxel) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Pregnancy after Stage IV diagnosis Jejik CAROLINE77

Posts.Content: May 5, 2012 09:54PM Jejik wrote: Thanks y'all for the lovely comments! With the clean scan and baby looking good on ultrasound, I feel like I can finally get excited. LuAnn, to answer your question, the last time I had a PET scan in August 2011 I was NED, and since my liver is still clear, I am hoping I am still good. I have had so much breast pain, I sometimes worry about a local recurrence, but I think it is probably just my breast is getting bigger, and stretching out my lumpectomy scar. I feel so blessed since I hadn't even been on herceptin a year when I had to stop it. Not to mention that one of my doctors told me that getting pregnant was the worst thing that could ever happen. Names....Oh my goodness. Having such a hard time. I was convinced it was a boy, and had what I thought was the perfect name picked out (Lincoln), but a girl seems so much harder! I have a list of about 20 names, ha ha. Some of the contenders: Beatrix, Moxie, Esme, Lucia, Mokino (japanese word for possibility/hope), Rhiannon, Flannery,Charlotte, Ione, Naureen, Adia...Any input suggested...although my mom has already told me my names are all weird, so I am well aware of that, lol.  Hope you all are having good weekends. I keep y'all in my good thoughts/prayer/positive vibe mental bin daily!
Posts.Title: Pregnancy after Stage IV diagnosis Jejik CAROLINE77

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2012 02:26AM Jejik wrote: Dha and bryses...I am sorry I missed your posts. Bryses, I was in your shoes not too long ago, and know how hard that decision is. Please keep us updated how you are doing. Dha, maybe you could ask for an MRI of the areas giving you trouble? As long as they do them without contrast they are safe for the baby. I have been having a lot of shoulder pain myself. I have chalked it up to my breast getting bigger, and the effect that is having on the lumpectomy site and where they removed the lymph nodes. I have also noticed some cording I didn't have before. Are you seeing your oncologist at all during your pregnancy? Even if not, it is probably worth giving him or her a call!

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2012 06:38AM Jejik wrote: Tammie, I am so sorry to hear this. You must be so scared. The hospital is the best place for him, and I pray they can get to the bottom of what is causing the psychosis. Like someone else mentioned, I am not sure though, that putting off your second opinion is necessarily the best choice. While I am sure for your peace of mind, it will be good to be close to him, I am not sure a day or two will make a difference to him, especially if he is experiencing psychosis. I have bipolar disorder, and have been in more than one mental hospital...in varying degrees of mental upset. I know that it usually takes more than a day or two to be stabilized, and they usually cannot or will not give you a diagnosis right away.Visiting hour is usually just an hour, and depending on one's mental state at the time of that hour, sometimes a patient cannot even see their visitors.Also, if you were my mom, I would really want you to go to the second opinion. There just is so little you can do for him at this point, I feel like what you can do is take care of yourself. But you are a mom, and I know how my mom is, so...all the best to you in whatever you decide. Lastly, it does seem quick to rush to a schizophrenia diagnosis. I know that psychosis can happen in other mental coditions, including bipolar. In any event, if this is some type of mental illness, I encourage you to check out your local chapter of NAMI...the national alliance on mental illness. This is an organization founded by family members of people with a mental illness designed to provide education, support and resources to those living with a mental illness and their family members. It has been an invaluable support to my mother and I. They also have a national web site NAMI.org. Please keep us posted.
Posts.Title: Not making it to 2nd opinion OT tammie bhd1

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2012 10:50PM Jejik wrote: I haven't had to stop herceptin because of a low injection fraction, although my last MUGA I was down to 50%. I never noticed any problems. I do know how scary it is to go off Herceptin, though, especially when it has kept you NED. I was NED after I finished TCH, and had been on herceptin alone for about eight (?) months, and was still doing well. But then I was surprised with a pregnancy, so I have been on a herceptin break for about eight months now. My doctors felt that, I I was going to continue with the Pregnancy, I should go off the herceptin until I had the baby. They are inducing me at 37 wks so I can get back on it. I feel great, so I am hoping this temporary pause with herceptin hasn't set me back to far. I haven't had a pet scan since I finished radiation about a year ago. I will have one a couple weeks after the baby is born, and I Won't know until then what the cancer has been up to. Ii really feel for you. Being off herceptin is a constant worry, like I am doing nothing to stop the cancer. In your case, three months is a long time, but not forever. Have you asked your oncologist what could happen in that three Months? You will be in my thoughts!

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2012 07:26PM Jejik wrote: I have never lost a parent, but I thought I would share what I am doing. While I think memories are great to hold onto, they don't really work when your children are still little. I have been filling out an about my mom type journal that my mom got me at a bookstore. It just has these prompts for stories or memories about my life. I also write in a journal that I will leave for my daughter to read when she is older. I am pregnant, haven't had her yet, so right now I mostly talk about the pregnancy and what I would like her to know for the future. I also plan to keep mementos from her childhood with notes where I describe a memory attached with them. Like "your first outfit" or "book you asked me to read over and over." At some point, I will probably make a video...just because I think it would be awful to have no idea what your mom was like in person, and at least in a video she can see what I sound like and my facial expressions.

Posts.Content: May 16, 2012 09:46PM Jejik wrote: Just a word of caution...I wouldn't take advice on how much you can earn or whether it is permissable to work while you receive diaability benefis from someone on a website, whether they say they are a lawyer or are merely repeating what a lawyer said. Especially when you have no way of knowing their credentials, how up to date their information is, or what their understanding of not just regulations but also the case law is. I know several people who work part time after receiving disability and still receive disability, but I don't know the differences or similarities in your case versus theirs. To initiate a social security claim, you have to fill out the paperwork yourself.There may be resources in your community or through your cancer center to help with a paperwork. Most (if not all) lawyers will not get involved until you have been denied. Best of luck to you!

Go out for a good local meal tomorrow, take in a museum, enjoy the sights...hugs to you!

Posts.Title: Doctors who think they are God CoolBreeze CoolBreeze

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2012 06:01PM Jejik wrote: I love some of these responses. Today I had a checkup for my pregnancy and the nurse, who I had never spoken to before started asking me all these questions about my breast cancer...how I found it if I had to have a masectomy...on and on and then she asked what my prognosis was. Not because it was relevant to what she was doing...she was just unhooking me from a monitor. Wth? Who asks someone that because they are curious! I just said well there is no cure so i will eventually die from it but with new therapies women are living longer and longer. If I didn't have to go back there every week I think I might have gotten sarcastic with her. It just seems so insensitive. It is funny because I switched to this OB office two months ago because the ones in my other practice always wanted to comment about my cancer, and i felt like they werent focusing on the baby. These docs know that, and have never even said the word cancer to me. Maybe that is why I was so taken aback by the nurse's prying. On the other hand, I try to chalk up such experiences to helping educate people about breast cancer. Do any of you ever look at it that way? Never thought I would have to educate a nurse though. Sigh

Posts.Title: Not a club I want to be in... mlo69 christina0001

Posts.Content: May 13, 2012 10:47AM Jejik wrote: Being pregnant, I can relate to the frustration and fears and fears of the other moms to kids. It is so terrifying to think I won't have a chance to teach my daughter all the things and values that I feel she will need to know in life. And I haven't even met her yet. I always get frustrated when others say they know how I feel, or when my husband says well I could Die before you or someone says no one knows what time we have. I think unless one has a terminal illness like we do they will never understand how we feel. But people always want to say they do, I have never gotten that. Just like I don't like people comparing their situation to mine, I try not to minimize other people's feelings who are in a situation that is objectively not as "bad" as mine. I think people only know what they know. And someone always has it is worse. But that gets hard when people say things like "I know exactly how you feel." To three little girls, that is a great idea about asking a few of your friends to step up so your kids can have a wide array Of influences. Thanks for sharing. Seems like the mods have been trying to work on some of the problems, I hope the problem with stage Iv forum gets fixed sooner rather than later. I
Posts.Title: No, you don't understand... Stormynyte Reneepals
